message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Deep learning, reinforcement learning, and world models
Paper Abstract: Deep learning (DL) and reinforcement learning (RL) methods seem to be a part of indispensable factors to achieve human-level or super-human AI systems. On the other hand, both DL and RL have strong connections with our brain functions and with neuroscientific findings. In this review, we summarize talks and discussions in the "Deep Learning and Reinforcement Learning" session of the symposium, International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Brain Science. In this session, we discussed whether we can achieve comprehensive understanding of human intelligence based on the recent advances of deep learning and reinforcement learning algorithms. Speakers contributed to provide talks about their recent studies that can be key technologies to achieve human-level intelligence.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Deep Learning:

## Overview

Deep learning refers to a class of machine learning algorithms in which a hierarchy of layers is used to transform input data into a progressively more abstract and composite representation.

## Key Characteristics

In machine learning, deep learning focuses on utilizing multilayered neural networks to perform tasks such as classification, regression, and representation learning.(no content)The adjective "deep" refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.

## How It Works

The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and revolves around stacking artificial neurons into layers and "training" them to process data. Unlike traditional machine learning, in the deep learning approach, features are not hand-crafted and the model discovers useful feature representations from the data automatically.

## Common Architectures

Some common deep learning network architectures include fully connected networks, deep belief networks, recurrent neural networks, convolutional neural networks, generative adversarial networks, transformers, and neural radiance fields.

## Applications

These architectures have been applied to fields including computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, machine translation, bioinformatics, drug design, medical image analysis, climate science, material inspection and board game playing.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Deep Learning:

## Overview

Deep learning refers to a class of machine learning algorithms in which a hierarchy of layers is used to transform input data into a progressively more abstract and composite representation.

## Key Characteristics

In machine learning, deep learning focuses on utilizing multilayered neural networks to perform tasks such as classification, regression, and representation learning.(no content)The adjective "deep" refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.

## How It Works

The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and revolves around stacking artificial neurons into layers and "training" them to process data. Unlike traditional machine learning, in the deep learning approach, features are not hand-crafted and the model discovers useful feature representations from the data automatically.

## Common Architectures

Some common deep learning network architectures include fully connected networks, deep belief networks, recurrent neural networks, convolutional neural networks, generative adversarial networks, transformers, and neural radiance fields.

## Applications

These architectures have been applied to fields including computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, machine translation, bioinformatics, drug design, medical image analysis, climate science, material inspection and board game playing.

Web search results for query: "Reinforcement learning"

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of reinforcement learning based on the search results:

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## How It Works

Reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)The agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Key Concepts

The environment is typically stated in the form of a Markov decision process, as many reinforcement learning algorithms use dynamic programming techniques.(no content)Two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples to optimize performance, and the use of function approximation to deal with large environments.

## Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Deep Reinforcement Learning

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.(no content)In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics.

I've performed a web search for "Neuroscience brain" and found comprehensive information. Here's an overview of what neuroscience is and how it relates to the brain:

## Definition of Neuroscience

Neuroscience is the scientific study of the nervous system (the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nervous system), its functions, and its disorders.(no content)It is a multidisciplinary science that combines physiology, anatomy, molecular biology, developmental biology, cytology, psychology, physics, computer science, chemistry, medicine, statistics, and mathematical modeling to understand the fundamental and emergent properties of neurons, glia, and neural circuits.

## Key Research Areas

The understanding of the biological basis of learning, memory, behavior, perception, and consciousness has been described by Eric Kandel as the "epic challenge" of the biological sciences.

## Modern Approaches and Techniques

The techniques used by neuroscientists have expanded enormously, from molecular and cellular studies of individual neurons to imaging of sensory, motor, and cognitive tasks in the brain. Advanced imaging methods like MRI and brain mapping are now central tools in neuroscience research.

## Historical Development

During the 20th century, neuroscience began to be recognized as a distinct academic discipline in its own right, rather than as studies of the nervous system within other disciplines.

The field continues to evolve with new technologies and methodologies enabling researchers to understand the brain and nervous system at multiple scales—from individual neurons to complex cognitive processes.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

Here are the search results for "Artificial intelligence":

## Overview

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## Core Research Areas

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Current Applications

Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. These include architecture, content analysis, video surveillance, music composition, and more. Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

The search results contain comprehensive information about various aspects of artificial intelligence, including its applications, history, research methods, and future directions.

Here are the search results for "Artificial intelligence":

## Overview

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## Core Research Areas

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Current Applications

Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. These include architecture, content analysis, video surveillance, music composition, and more. Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

The search results contain comprehensive information about various aspects of artificial intelligence, including its applications, history, research methods, and future directions.

Web search results for query: "World models artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Foundation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_model"},{"title":"Agentic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Model-based reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_reasoning"},{"title":"Generative artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Competition in artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_in_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Glossary of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"History of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Open-source artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Explainable artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inscrutable_artificial_intelligence"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about world models in artificial intelligence:

## Definition and Purpose

World models, alongside embodied AI, multi-agent models, and neuroscience models of the brain, are seen as alternatives to large language models for achieving general artificial intelligence.(no content)World models do not have a fully agreed definition, but have been divided into two scopes: one for representing and understanding the current environment, and another for predicting the future state of that environment.

## Technical Approaches

In the former view, world models are developed using model-based reinforcement learning and a Markov decision process, using model predictive control or Monte Carlo tree search to create policies. With the latter, (multimodal) large language models or video generation models can be used.

## Recent Developments

TechCrunch saw Sora as an example of a world model, while in January 2025, Nvidia released its own set of world models.(no content)Google DeepMind has also released two world models in two-dimensional space and three-dimensional space, respectively, that were trained on video data, with Google claiming that the latter can be a training environment for AI agents.(no content)Meta released a world model in June 2025, Tencent released an open source world model in July 2025.

## Challenges and Concerns

TechCrunch noted that world models could use more data than large language models and would require significantly more computational power (including the use of thousands of GPUs for training and inference). Additionally, in 2025, world models are being applied to drone warfare, robotics, and self-driving vehicles.

Web search results for query: "Intelligence cognitive ability"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence"},{"title":"g factor (psychometrics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G_factor_(psychometrics)"},{"title":"Human intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_intelligence"},{"title":"Cognitive skill - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_skill"},{"title":"Cognitive test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_test"},{"title":"Intelligence quotient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence_quotient"},{"title":"Cattell–Horn–Carroll theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattell–Horn–Carroll_theory"},{"title":"Fluid and crystallized intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid_and_crystallized_intelligence"},{"title":"Three-stratum theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-stratum_theory"},{"title":"Cognitive Abilities Test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_Abilities_Test"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about intelligence and cognitive ability:

## Definition of Intelligence and Cognitive Ability

Human intelligence is the intellectual power of humans, which is marked by complex cognitive feats and high levels of motivation and self-awareness.(no content)Intelligence has been defined in many ways: the capacity for abstraction, logic, understanding, self-awareness, learning, emotional knowledge, reasoning, planning, creativity, critical thinking, and problem-solving.(no content)Intelligence gives humans the cognitive abilities to learn, form concepts, understand, and reason, including the capacities to recognize patterns, innovate, plan, solve problems, and employ language to communicate.

## Key Distinction

Intelligence is different from learning. Learning refers to the act of retaining facts and information or abilities and being able to recall them for future use. Intelligence, on the other hand, is the cognitive ability of someone to perform these and other processes.

## Types of Intelligence

The research identifies several distinct types of intelligence:

- Emotional intelligence is thought to be the ability to convey emotion to others in an understandable way as well as to read the emotions of other
- Social intelligence is the ability to understand the social cues and motivations of others and oneself in social situations.
- Moral intelligence is the capacity to understand right from wrong and to behave based on the value that is believed to be right.

## Cognitive Ability Components

Cognitive skills include literacy, self-reflection, logical reasoning, abstract thinking, critical thinking, introspection and mental arithmetic. Cognitive skills vary in processing complexity, and can range from more fundamental processes such as perception and various memory functions, to more sophisticated processes such as decision making, problem solving and metacognition.

## Major Theoretical Frameworks

Fluid intelligence (Gf) was hypothesized as the ability to solve novel problems by using reasoning, and crystallized intelligence (Gc) was hypothesized as a knowledge-based ability that was very dependent on education and experience.(no content)Today, the Cattell–Horn–Carroll theory is widely accepted as the most comprehensive and empirically supported theory of cognitive abilities, informing a substantial body of research and the ongoing development of IQ (Intelligence Quotient) tests.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity, entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks are complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

This paper is classified as a **survey** because it summarizes talks and discussions from a symposium reviewing existing advances in deep learning and reinforcement learning, rather than proposing new methods.

**Extracted Triples (6 total):**

1. **Deep learning** (method) - Core method for achieving human-level intelligence through hierarchical neural networks
2. **Reinforcement learning** (method) - Essential paradigm for training agents through environmental interaction
3. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - The overarching field for creating human-level or super-human cognitive systems
4. **World models** (concept) - AI systems for understanding and predicting environmental dynamics (mentioned in title)
5. **Neuroscience** (concept) - Biological foundations linking AI methods to brain functions
6. **Human intelligence** (concept) - The target capability that AI systems aim to match or exceed

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED

All triples include proper Wikipedia URLs, entity types, relations, and relevance descriptions. The paper meets validation requirements with 6 "uses" relations (consistent with a survey paper) and valid entity classifications.

Sources:
- [Deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning)
